slides.mascot_explanation: We already learned a little about the ancient Olympics in history, right? This slide reminds us that the Greeks had super important ideas about being an athlete. They believed in trying your very best (that's ARETE!), being honorable and respectful (that's TIME!), and earning fame that lasts forever (that's KLEOS!).

slides.text: Read the text aloud. Pause at key moments to discuss: 'Why did athletes train so hard? What did winning mean to them? It was not just about a medal — it was about bringing honor to their city-state and being remembered forever.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to read our book! As we read, we'll stop and talk about why those ancient athletes worked so hard. Think about what winning really meant to them – it wasn't just about a prize, but about making their families and cities proud and being remembered!

slides.text: After reading, discuss sportsmanship: 'What does it mean to compete with honor? Is winning the only thing that matters? The Greeks believed HOW you competed was just as important as whether you won. Even today, we admire athletes who show good sportsmanship.'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish the story, we'll talk about something called sportsmanship. Have you ever played a game and seen someone be a really good winner or a good loser? We'll discuss what it means to compete fairly and with respect, just like the Greeks believed was so important.

slides.prompt: In your journal, write a response: 'If I competed in the ancient Olympics, I would choose [event] because...' Describe your training, the competition, and whether you win or lose — and how you show good sportsmanship either way. Write at least one full paragraph.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an ancient Olympian! In your journal, you're going to write about which event you would have competed in. Imagine how you'd train, what the competition would be like, and how you'd show good sportsmanship no matter if you won or lost.

slides.text: The Olympic spirit is about more than winning. It is about pushing yourself to be the best you can be, competing fairly, and respecting your opponents. These values from Ancient Greece are still important today in sports and in life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student articulate Greek athletic values and write a thoughtful response about competition and sportsmanship?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned that the Olympic spirit is all about trying your hardest, playing fair, and respecting others. Those amazing ideas from long ago are still super important for athletes today, and even for us in our everyday lives. You really explored the spirit of the games!

parent_notes: The Olympic theme naturally opens discussions about sportsmanship, hard work, and fair play — values that extend beyond athletics. The Greek concept of arete (striving for personal excellence) is particularly Montessori-aligned: it is about being your best self, not being better than others. This is a great opportunity to talk about effort vs. outcome.

title: Poetry — Haiku and Imagery
description: Students learn about haiku, the Japanese poetry form with a 5-7-5 syllable structure. They practice counting syllables, analyzing imagery in haiku, and writing their own haiku about nature.
instructions:
1. Introduce haiku: a Japanese form, but we connect it to poetry study.
2. Structure: 3 lines, 5-7-5 syllables. Count syllables by clapping.
3. Practice counting syllables in words: but-ter-fly (3), el-e-phant (3), cat (1), beau-ti-ful (3).
4. Read several haiku. Discuss: haiku capture a single moment in nature. They paint a picture with very few words.
5. The power of IMAGERY: using words that appeal to the senses (sight, sound, touch, smell, taste).
6. Write haiku together: choose a nature subject, brainstorm sensory words, fit them to 5-7-5.
7. Students write 3 original haiku about nature.
materials_needed: Collection of haiku (Basho, Issa are classic)

slides.heading: Poetry
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title of our lesson! It tells us we're going to be learning about a special kind of poem called a haiku, and how poets use words to make us see, hear, and feel things, which is called imagery.

slides.setup_instructions: Select 6-8 classic haiku translated into English. Display nature photographs for inspiration. Have the syllable counting strategy reviewed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the tools we'll need for our poetry adventure! We have a "Haiku collection" which is like a book of amazing poems, a "Writing journal" to write our own poems in, "Pencils" to do the writing, "Nature images" that will give us ideas, and a "Syllable guide" to help us count beats in words. You'll need to gather these things with a grown-up's help.

slides.text: 'Today we travel to Japan for a special poetry form: HAIKU! A haiku has only three lines and follows a strict syllable pattern: 5 syllables in line 1, 7 syllables in line 2, and 5 syllables in line 3. That is only 17 syllables total! But a great haiku can paint an entire picture.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super exciting because we're starting our haiku journey! Haiku is a special type of poem that comes from Japan, and it has a super neat rule: it's always made of just three lines, and each line has a certain number of little beats called syllables. The first line has 5 beats, the second has 7 beats, and the third line has 5 beats again.

slides.text: 'First, let us practice counting syllables. Clap each beat: wa-ter (2), moun-tain (2), but-ter-fly (3), el-e-phant (3). Now let us read this haiku by Basho: An old si-lent pond (5) / A frog jumps in-to the pond (7) / Splash! Si-lence a-gain (5). Can you see the picture? Can you HEAR the splash?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to practice counting those poem beats, called syllables! When you say a word, some parts sound longer, like they have their own little clap. We can clap out syllables like in "but-ter-fly" (clap, clap, clap - 3 beats!). Then we'll read a real haiku and try to hear the sounds and see the picture it makes, just like a real poet!

slides.text: 'Haiku use IMAGERY — words that make you see, hear, feel, smell, or taste something. The best haiku capture one single moment in nature. Let us write one together. Our subject: a sunset. What do we see? What colors? What do we feel? Let us fit our best words into 5-7-5.' Compose on the board.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn about "imagery," which is like using magic words to paint a picture in someone's mind! Poets use words that help us see colors, hear sounds, or even feel things. We're going to pick a nature picture, like a sunset, and think of words that describe it using our senses, then we'll try to fit those words into our 5-7-5 haiku pattern.

slides.prompt: Write 3 original haiku about nature. Choose different subjects: a season, an animal, weather, a flower, the ocean. Remember: 5-7-5 syllables. Use imagery — paint a picture with your words! Count syllables carefully by clapping. Illustrate your favorite haiku.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be a poet! Your job now is to write three of your very own haiku about nature, like a cozy animal, a rainy day, or a pretty flower. Remember to count your syllables carefully by clapping them out, and try to use those amazing imagery words to paint a picture for your reader. You can even draw a picture for your favorite one!

slides.text: Haiku show us that sometimes less is more. Just 17 syllables can capture a beautiful moment forever. The Japanese poet Basho said: 'Do not follow in the footsteps of the old poets — seek what they sought.' Find your own moments of beauty in nature!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student count syllables accurately and write original haiku following the 5-7-5 structure with nature imagery?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we did it! We learned that even with just 17 syllables, a haiku can capture a whole moment in nature, like a tiny snapshot. You've learned how to count syllables and write your own poems that make people see and feel things. Remember to keep looking for those special moments in nature, just like the poets do!

parent_notes: Haiku is perfect for young poets because the constraints are simple yet challenging. Counting syllables builds phonological awareness, and the imagery requirement develops descriptive writing skills. Go outside with your child and observe nature closely — this is the best inspiration for haiku. Traditional haiku include a seasonal reference (kigo). Basho, Issa, and Buson are the three great classical haiku masters.

title: Measurement — Word Problems with Length
description: Students solve multi-step word problems involving metric length measurement, conversion, and the four operations. Problems are set in historical and everyday contexts.
instructions:
1. Review conversion: cm to m and back.
2. Solve problems together, modeling the problem-solving process:
   - 'A Greek stadion track was about 192 meters long. How many centimeters is that?'
   - 'Three ribbon pieces measure 45 cm, 62 cm, and 38 cm. What is the total length? Convert to meters.'
3. Multi-step: 'A rope is 3 meters long. You cut off 85 cm. How much is left? (Convert to same unit first.)'
4. Comparison: 'Who jumped farther: Amir at 2.1 m or Sofia at 195 cm?'
5. Students solve 8 word problems independently.
6. Create their own measurement word problem.

slides.heading: Measurement
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title page for our math adventure today! It tells us we're going to be working with "Measurement" and specifically focusing on "Word Problems with Length," which means we'll be solving puzzles about how long things are.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 8-10 word problems of varying difficulty. Include problems with historical context (Greek measurements, Silk Road distances, Great Wall length).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready! We need the worksheet with all the word problems, a whiteboard and pencils to do our math work, a ruler and a meter stick to measure things, and a conversion chart to help us switch between different units like centimeters and meters. These will help us solve the problems just like real scientists use their equipment.

slides.text: 'Today we use our measurement skills to solve real problems. Remember the problem-solving steps: (1) READ carefully, (2) IDENTIFY what you need to find, (3) DECIDE the operation, (4) CONVERT to the same unit if needed, (5) SOLVE, (6) CHECK if the answer makes sense.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our superhero guide for solving word problems! It shows us the secret steps real mathematicians use: first, we read the problem super carefully, then figure out what we need to find, choose the right math operation (like adding or subtracting), make sure all our measurements are in the same units, do the math, and finally, check if our answer makes sense.

slides.text: Model: 'A Greek stadion track was about 192 m. The Parthenon is 70 m long. How much longer is the track? 192 - 70 = 122 m longer. Check: 192 is roughly 200, 70 is roughly 70, 200 - 70 = 130. Our answer 122 is close, so it makes sense.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see a problem in action! This shows us how to figure out how much longer one thing is than another, like comparing the length of a Greek track to the Parthenon. We subtract the shorter length from the longer one, and then we check our answer by rounding the numbers to see if our answer is close, which is a super smart way to make sure we didn't make a mistake!

slides.text: Model a conversion problem: 'A rope is 3 m long. You cut off 85 cm. How much is left? First, make the units the same: 3 m = 300 cm. Now: 300 - 85 = 215 cm = 2 m 15 cm = 2.15 m. Always convert to the same unit before adding or subtracting!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a tricky one, but we can do it! When we need to add or subtract lengths that are in different units, like meters and centimeters, we have to change them so they're the same first. The slide shows us how to turn 3 meters into 300 centimeters so we can easily subtract the 85 centimeters we cut off, and then we can even turn our answer back into meters!

slides.prompt: Solve 8 measurement word problems. Show your work, convert units when needed, and check each answer with estimation. Then create your own measurement word problem with an answer key — make it challenging! Use a historical or real-world context.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be the math detective! You'll solve 8 word problems, showing all your thinking and converting units when you need to, just like we practiced. After that, you get to be the teacher and create your VERY OWN measurement word problem, maybe about something from history or a real-life thing, and make sure it's a good challenge for someone else to solve!

slides.text: The key to measurement word problems: always make sure you are working with the SAME units before adding, subtracting, or comparing. Convert first, then compute. Estimation helps you check — if your answer seems way off, recheck your work!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student solve multi-step word problems involving metric length measurement and conversion between units?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! The most important thing to remember is that you *always* have to make sure your measurements are in the same units before you add, subtract, or compare them – like making sure everything is in centimeters or everything is in meters. And don't forget to use your estimation skills to double-check your answers; it's like giving your math a quick hug to make sure it's right!

parent_notes: Word problems combining measurement and conversion are challenging because they require multiple steps. The most common error is operating on numbers with different units (adding cm to m without converting). Encourage your child to always write the units alongside the numbers. Creating their own word problems demonstrates deep understanding — a student who can write a good problem truly understands the concept.

title: Invertebrates — Mollusks
description: Students learn about mollusks: soft-bodied animals that often have shells. They study the three main groups (gastropods, bivalves, cephalopods) and examine shell structures.
instructions:
1. Review: arthropods have exoskeletons and jointed legs. Mollusks are different!
2. Mollusk characteristics: soft body, muscular foot, mantle (may produce a shell), most have a radula (toothed tongue).
3. Three groups:
   - Gastropods: one shell or none, one foot — snails, slugs
   - Bivalves: two shells hinged together — clams, mussels, oysters
   - Cephalopods: tentacles, most intelligent invertebrates — octopus, squid, nautilus
4. Show shells if available. Examine shell structure with magnifying glass.
5. Discuss: octopuses are incredibly intelligent — they can solve puzzles, open jars, and change color!
6. Students draw and label examples from each group.
7. Compare mollusks to arthropods.

slides.heading: Invertebrates
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our new adventure! It's introducing us to a whole group of amazing animals called mollusks, and it tells us they have soft bodies, but sometimes they wear hard shells. Isn't it cool how nature gives some animals a built-in suit of armor?

slides.setup_instructions: Display seashells for examination. Print clear images of snails, clams, octopus, squid, and nautilus. Have magnifying glasses ready for shell study.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our mollusk exploration! We've got a collection of real seashells to look at, magnifying glasses so we can see tiny details, pictures of different mollusks, and paper and crayons for drawing. Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help so we can get started!

slides.text: 'We have studied arthropods: insects, arachnids, and crustaceans — all with hard exoskeletons and jointed legs. Now meet the MOLLUSKS: soft-bodied animals. Their name comes from the Latin word mollis, meaning soft. Many protect their soft bodies with SHELLS, but some have no shell at all!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that we've already learned about animals like bugs and crabs with hard outside shells, right? Well, mollusks are different because they have soft bodies underneath, and their name even means "soft" in a language from long ago! Some mollusks have shells, but others don't have any at all.

slides.text: 'Three main mollusk groups: GASTROPODS (stomach-foot) include snails and slugs — they glide on a single muscular foot. BIVALVES (two-valves) have two shells hinged together — clams, mussels, and oysters. They open their shells to feed and snap them shut for protection.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we meet the three main families of mollusks! First are gastropods, like snails, that have one shell and slide around on a single, strong foot. Then we have bivalves, like clams, which are like little boxes with two shells that open and close.

slides.text: 'The most incredible mollusks are CEPHALOPODS (head-foot): octopuses, squid, and nautilus. Their tentacles grow from their heads! Octopuses have no shell at all but are the smartest invertebrates — they can solve puzzles, open jars, escape tanks, and even change color and texture in an instant!' Show images.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super-duper interesting ones: cephalopods! These are like octopuses and squid, and they have arms called tentacles growing right from their heads! The octopus is like the super-genius of the soft-bodied animals because they can figure out tricky things and even change their color to hide.

slides.prompt: Draw one example from each mollusk group: a gastropod (snail), a bivalve (clam), and a cephalopod (octopus). Label the key body parts: shell, foot, tentacles, mantle. Examine real shells with a magnifying glass and sketch the spiral or hinge patterns you see.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be artists! You're going to draw a snail, a clam, and an octopus, and then label the parts we learned about, like the shell or tentacles. Then, take a magnifying glass to those real shells and draw the cool patterns you see, like spirals or lines where they open.

slides.text: Mollusks are the second largest group of invertebrates after arthropods. From the humble garden snail to the brilliant octopus, they show incredible diversity. The beautiful shells you find at the beach were once homes for living mollusks!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student name the three mollusk groups, describe their characteristics, and give examples of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You explored all about mollusks, from their soft bodies to their amazing shells and super-smart octopus friends. Remember how incredible it is that those shells on the beach were once homes for these fascinating creatures? You totally nailed learning about them!

parent_notes: If you have seashells at home, this is a wonderful time to examine them closely. Children are often amazed to learn that octopuses are mollusks — related to clams and snails! Octopus intelligence videos on YouTube are incredible and age-appropriate. If you can visit an aquarium or tide pools, the mollusk lesson comes alive. Collect and classify shells at the beach by gastropod vs. bivalve.

title: Geometry — Perimeter of Polygons
description: Students learn the concept of perimeter as the distance around a shape. They measure and calculate the perimeters of various polygons using rulers and addition.
instructions:
1. Introduce perimeter: the distance AROUND the outside of a shape. Peri = around, meter = measure.
2. Walk the perimeter of the room: count steps along each wall, add them up.
3. Demonstrate with a rectangle: measure all 4 sides, add them. P = l + w + l + w = 2l + 2w.
4. For regular shapes (equal sides): P = number of sides x side length.
5. Practice: measure and calculate the perimeter of 5 shapes (rectangle, triangle, pentagon, hexagon, irregular polygon).
6. Word problems: 'A garden is 8 m long and 5 m wide. How much fencing is needed?'
7. Connect to Greek architecture: calculate the perimeter of the Parthenon base.
materials_needed: Polygon shapes (cardboard or paper, various sizes)

slides.heading: Geometry
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure today! It tells us we're going to be exploring something called "Geometry," which is all about shapes, and specifically, we'll learn about the "Perimeter of Polygons." Think of it as learning the secret code to measure the outside edges of shapes!

slides.setup_instructions: Cut out various polygon shapes from cardboard. Include regular and irregular polygons. Prepare word problems involving perimeter.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer gear ready! We've got rulers to measure how long things are, different polygon shapes like triangles and squares to work with, and some string that might be helpful for curved edges. We also have a whiteboard for writing and a worksheet with practice problems, kind of like a treasure map for our math mission!

slides.text: 'PERIMETER means the distance around the outside of a shape. If an ant walked along every edge of this rectangle and ended up back where it started, the distance it walked is the perimeter! The word comes from Greek: peri (around) + metron (measure). Let us walk the perimeter of our room!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important because it teaches us what "perimeter" means. Imagine a tiny ant walking all the way around the edge of a shape until it gets back to where it started – the total distance the ant walked is the perimeter! "Peri" means "around" and "meter" means "to measure," so perimeter is just measuring the distance around.

slides.text: 'To find the perimeter: measure each side and add them all up. This rectangle is 12 cm long and 8 cm wide: P = 12 + 8 + 12 + 8 = 40 cm. Shortcut for rectangles: P = 2 x length + 2 x width = 2(12) + 2(8) = 24 + 16 = 40 cm. Same answer!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning a cool trick for finding the perimeter of rectangles! We can measure each of the four sides and add them all up. For a rectangle, there's an even faster way: just add the length and width together, and then double it, because opposite sides of a rectangle are always the same length!

slides.text: 'For REGULAR polygons (all sides equal), it is even easier: just multiply! An equilateral triangle with sides of 5 cm: P = 3 x 5 = 15 cm. A regular hexagon with sides of 4 cm: P = 6 x 4 = 24 cm. But for irregular shapes, you must measure every side and add.' Practice with shapes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us an even quicker way to find the perimeter if a shape is "regular," which means all its sides are exactly the same length. For shapes like a square or an equilateral triangle, you can just multiply the number of sides by the length of one side. But remember, for shapes with different side lengths, you still have to measure and add them all up!

slides.prompt: Measure and calculate the perimeter of 5 shapes using your ruler. Record the length of each side and the total perimeter. Then solve: A Greek temple base is a rectangle 70 m long and 31 m wide. What is the perimeter? How much rope would you need to go around it twice?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to put your detective skills to work! You get to measure the edges of five different shapes and add up the lengths to find their perimeters. Then, you'll solve a fun problem about a Greek temple – imagine needing to know how much rope to go around it, maybe to decorate it for a party!

slides.text: Perimeter is the distance around any shape. Add up all the sides! For rectangles: P = 2(l + w). For regular polygons: P = sides x length. Perimeter is used whenever you need to know how much material goes AROUND something: fencing, picture frames, borders, and edging.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student measure sides of polygons and calculate their perimeters using addition or multiplication?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned that perimeter is just the distance all the way around any shape, and you got really good at measuring sides and adding them up. You even learned shortcuts for rectangles and regular shapes, which is super smart, and now you know how perimeter helps us figure out how much fencing or trim we might need for real-world things!

parent_notes: Perimeter is a highly practical concept. Help your child find real-world applications: how much ribbon to wrap around a box, how much fencing for a garden, the distance around a picture frame. The distinction between perimeter (around the edge) and area (the space inside, coming in a later week) is important — do not introduce area yet, but if your child asks about the space inside, preview the concept briefly.

title: Greek Theater — Masks and Drama
description: Students learn about the origins of theater in Ancient Greece and create their own theatrical masks. They explore how Greek actors used masks to portray characters and emotions.
instructions:
1. Theater was invented in Ancient Greece! The word 'theater' comes from Greek theatron (viewing place).
2. Greek theaters were semicircular, open-air, and could seat thousands.
3. Actors wore MASKS to show different characters and emotions. Masks amplified their voices.
4. Two main types of plays: TRAGEDY (serious, sad) and COMEDY (funny, lighthearted).
5. The two mask symbols (happy and sad faces) still represent theater today.
6. Students create their own Greek-style masks from paper plates:
   - Choose tragedy or comedy
   - Design the face with exaggerated expression
   - Add hair, headdress, and decorations
7. Perform a short scene wearing the masks.
materials_needed: Yarn or paper strips for hair

slides.heading: Greek Theater
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our exciting adventure into ancient Greece! It tells us we're going to learn all about something called "Greek Theater," and how actors used special masks for their shows. Isn't it neat that something so old can still be so fun?

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-cut eye holes in paper plates if students are young. Display images of Greek theater masks and amphitheaters. Have all craft materials organized.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our super-secret crafting supplies ready! We've got paper plates that will become our masks, scissors to carefully cut with, craft sticks to hold them, and glue to stick everything together. We'll also use paint or markers to give our masks faces, yarn for awesome hair, and other fun decorations to make them look amazing, just like the ones in the pictures of old Greek masks!

slides.text: 'Did you know that THEATER was invented in Ancient Greece? The Greeks built huge open-air theaters cut into hillsides — some could hold 15,000 people! Actors performed plays about myths, heroes, and everyday life. The word theater comes from the Greek word theatron, meaning a place for viewing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, get this – theater, like plays and acting, was actually invented way, way back in Ancient Greece! They built giant outdoor theaters, kind of like big circles on hills where thousands of people could sit and watch. The word "theater" even comes from a Greek word that means "a place for viewing," so it's like they invented the whole idea of watching shows!

slides.text: 'Greek actors wore large MASKS to show different characters and emotions. A single actor might play multiple roles by switching masks! The mouths were shaped like megaphones to project the voice. There were two main types of plays: TRAGEDY (serious, often ending sadly) and COMEDY (funny, ending happily). The happy and sad face masks are still the symbol of theater today!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine actors wearing giant masks that showed if they were happy or sad, or if they were playing a king or a funny character! These masks were super important because they helped everyone in the huge theater see the actor's feelings, and they even helped make their voices louder, like a built-in megaphone. The two most famous masks, the happy and sad faces, are still used to show theater today!

slides.text: 'Now we create our own Greek theater masks! Choose: will yours show TRAGEDY or COMEDY? For tragedy: downturned mouth, furrowed brow, sad eyes. For comedy: wide smile, raised eyebrows, laughing eyes. Make the expression BIG and exaggerated — the audience far away needs to see it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to become a mask maker! You get to choose if your mask will show a TRAGEDY, which is a serious story, or a COMEDY, which is a funny one. For a tragedy mask, you might draw a sad mouth and worried eyebrows, and for a comedy mask, a big smiley face and laughing eyes! Make the face super big and clear so everyone can see your character's feelings.

slides.prompt: Create a Greek theater mask: (1) Choose tragedy or comedy. (2) Cut eye holes in a paper plate. (3) Paint or color the face with an exaggerated expression. (4) Add hair with yarn or paper strips. (5) Glue a craft stick to hold it. Then put on your mask and perform a short scene: say 3-4 lines in character!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to make your own amazing Greek mask! First, decide if it's for a sad tragedy or a happy comedy, then carefully cut out the eye holes in your paper plate. Next, paint or color a big, exaggerated face onto the plate, add some cool yarn for hair, and glue on any extra decorations you like. Finally, attach a craft stick to the back so you can hold it up, and then practice saying a few lines in character!

slides.text: Every time you watch a movie, attend a play, or see actors perform on TV, you are enjoying something that began in Ancient Greece over 2,500 years ago! The Greeks gave us not just theater but also the words: drama, scene, chorus, and orchestra. Your masks connect you to this incredible tradition!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the origins of Greek theater and create a mask representing tragedy or comedy?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You just connected yourself to something super old and awesome that the Ancient Greeks started thousands of years ago – theater and drama! Think about all the movies and plays we enjoy today; they all started with those Greek actors and their amazing masks. You created your very own piece of that incredible history!

parent_notes: Greek theater is the ancestor of all Western performing arts. The mask-making project is highly engaging and can lead to home performances of simplified Greek myths. If possible, watch a short clip of a modern performance of a Greek play. The theater vocabulary is fun: drama, scene, chorus, tragedy, comedy, orchestra — all Greek words we still use. Consider staging a family mythology play with the masks!

title: Poetry — Anthology and Recitation
description: Students compile a personal poetry anthology from the week's work: free verse, couplets, limericks, and haiku. They select their best poem for a memorized recitation performance.
instructions:
1. Gather all poems written this week: free verse, couplets, limericks, haiku.
2. Students select their best work for their anthology. Revise and create final copies.
3. Design a cover for the anthology with a title and illustration.
4. Choose one poem to memorize and recite.
5. Practice recitation techniques: speak clearly, use expression, make eye contact, pause at line breaks.
6. Perform: each student recites their chosen poem for the group/family.
7. Celebrate with a poetry tea: listen to poems while enjoying tea (connecting to China unit!).
materials_needed: Blank booklet or stapled pages for anthology
Optional: tea and treats for poetry tea

slides.heading: Poetry
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our poetry adventure! It tells us that this week we've been writing all sorts of poems, and now we're going to put our favorites together into our own special book called an anthology, and then share one of our poems out loud.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare blank booklets by folding and stapling paper. Gather all poems written throughout the week. Set up a cozy recitation area.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for our poetry party! We'll need all the poems you wrote this week, some empty pages to make our anthology booklet, colorful pencils and markers for drawing, and regular pencils for writing. If you want to have a real poetry tea later, you can grab some tea and treats too!

slides.text: 'This week you became a POET! You wrote free verse, couplets, limericks, and haiku. Today we celebrate by creating your very own POETRY ANTHOLOGY — a collection of your best poems — and performing one poem for an audience.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've been busy being a poet this week! You wrote poems that flowed freely, poems with rhyming pairs, funny limericks, and short haiku. Now, we're going to pick out your very best ones to make a special book and then share one with everyone!

slides.text: 'First, look through all your poems. Choose your favorites and revise them one more time — fix any spelling, improve a word choice, make it the best it can be. Then copy each poem neatly into your anthology booklet. Illustrate each poem with a small drawing. Design a beautiful cover with a title like My Poems or [Your Name]'s Poetry Collection.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make your poetry book shine! Look through all the poems you wrote and pick the ones you like best. Read them one more time and fix any little things, like spelling or choosing even better words, then copy them carefully into your booklet. Don't forget to draw a picture for each poem and create a super cool cover with a title!

slides.text: 'Now choose ONE poem to RECITE from memory. Recitation tips: (1) Memorize it line by line, (2) Speak CLEARLY and SLOWLY, (3) Use EXPRESSION — let your voice show the poem's emotion, (4) Make eye contact with your audience, (5) Pause at line breaks to let the words breathe. Practice three times before performing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be a star! Choose just one poem that you really love to memorize and say out loud. To share it like a pro, try to say each word clearly and not too fast, let your voice show how the poem feels, look at the people listening, and take a little breath after each line. Practice it a few times so you feel ready!

slides.prompt: Compile your poetry anthology: revise your best poems, copy them neatly with illustrations, and design a cover. Then choose one poem, memorize it, and practice reciting it with expression. Perform for your audience!
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the grand finale where you get to show off your amazing work! First, finish putting your poetry anthology together by fixing up your poems, copying them neatly with drawings, and making a great cover. Then, pick your special poem, learn it by heart, and practice saying it with feeling, just like we talked about. Finally, share your poem with your audience!

slides.text: You are a published poet! Your anthology contains original poems in four different forms. Poetry gives us the power to capture moments, express feelings, and play with the music of language. Keep writing poems — you have the skills and the voice!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student compile an organized anthology and recite a poem from memory with expression and clarity?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are officially a poet with your very own published book of poems, and you even shared one out loud! You learned how poems can capture feelings and ideas, and how fun it is to play with words. Keep writing, because you have so many more amazing poems waiting inside you!

parent_notes: The poetry anthology is a keepsake worth preserving. Recitation builds confidence, public speaking skills, and deep engagement with language. After today, consider making poetry a regular part of your routine — many families enjoy a weekly poem read aloud at dinner. The ability to memorize and recite poetry is a valuable skill that exercises memory and builds a personal library of beautiful language.

title: Measurement — Review and Mixed Practice
description: Students review all metric length concepts from the week: measuring in cm and m, converting between units, estimating, and solving word problems. They complete a measurement challenge course.
instructions:
1. Quick review: units (mm, cm, m, km), benchmarks, conversion rules.
2. Measurement relay/challenge course: set up 6 stations around the room.
   - Station 1: Measure 3 objects in cm.
   - Station 2: Estimate, then measure 3 objects.
   - Station 3: Convert 5 measurements between cm and m.
   - Station 4: Solve 3 word problems.
   - Station 5: Measure perimeter of 2 shapes.
   - Station 6: Create a measurement word problem.
3. Review answers together.
4. Reflect: what was easy? What needs more practice?

slides.heading: Measurement Review
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big adventure today! It tells us we're going to be doing a "Measurement Review" and the super fun part is that we get to do it on a "Challenge Course." Get ready to use your measuring superpowers!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 6 stations around the room. Each station should have clear instruction cards, necessary tools, and recording sheets. Test each station yourself first.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our challenge. We've got rulers and meter sticks for measuring, some objects to measure at different stations, instruction cards to tell us what to do at each spot, recording sheets to write down our answers, and pencils. Make sure you have all these ready to go before we start the course!

slides.text: Quick review quiz: 'How many cm in 1 m? How many m in 1 km? What benchmark is about 1 cm? About 1 m? To go from m to cm, do we multiply or divide? By how much?' Rapid-fire review of all concepts.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a quick warm-up for our brains! We're going to do some fast questions about how metric units fit together. Think about how many centimeters are in a meter, or how many meters make up a kilometer. We'll also talk about things that are about the size of a centimeter or a meter, and how we move between units.

slides.text: 'Today: a Measurement Challenge Course! Six stations, each testing a different skill. You will measure, estimate, convert, solve word problems, find perimeters, and create your own problem. Record all your work neatly on your recording sheet. Take your time and be precise!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get excited, because this slide tells us about the Measurement Challenge Course we're going on today! It's like a series of mini-games where you'll get to practice everything we've learned about measuring. You'll measure things, guess how long they are, change units, solve tricky word problems, find the distance around shapes, and even make up your own problem!

slides.text: Explain each station briefly: 'Station 1: measure objects. Station 2: estimate then measure. Station 3: unit conversions. Station 4: word problems. Station 5: perimeter. Station 6: create a word problem. You have about 5 minutes per station. Ready? Begin!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide gives us a sneak peek at the six different stations we'll visit on our challenge course. We’ll be measuring objects, guessing and then measuring, changing units like centimeters to meters, solving word problems, finding the distance around shapes, and creating our own measurement problem. We’ll spend about five minutes at each station, so let's get started!

slides.prompt: Complete all 6 stations of the Measurement Challenge Course. At each station, follow the instructions carefully and record your work. When finished with all stations, review your answers and fix any mistakes. What was your strongest station? What do you want to practice more?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where the real challenge begins! We need to go to each of the six stations and follow the instructions carefully, writing down all our answers on our recording sheets. Once we've finished all six stations, we'll go back and check our work to make sure everything is just right. You've got this!

slides.text: Excellent work! You can now measure accurately, convert between metric units, estimate with benchmarks, solve word problems, and calculate perimeters. Measurement is a skill you will use every day for the rest of your life. Next week: mass and capacity!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student demonstrate proficiency in measuring, converting, estimating, and solving problems with metric length?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You completed the whole Measurement Challenge Course and showed off all your amazing skills. You are now a pro at measuring in centimeters and meters, converting between them, estimating lengths, solving word problems, and finding the distance around shapes. Measurement is super important for everything you do, and you're going to use it all the time!

parent_notes: The challenge course format makes review engaging and active. If setting up 6 stations is not practical at home, simply work through the 6 types of activities sequentially. The key is that your child gets practice with ALL the measurement skills covered this week. Identify any weak areas for additional practice. Next week extends measurement to mass (grams, kilograms) and capacity (liters, milliliters).

title: The Mediterranean World — Trade and Connection
description: Students explore the broader Mediterranean region, understanding how the sea connected diverse civilizations (Egypt, Greece, Phoenicia, Rome) through trade, creating one of history's first interconnected regions.
instructions:
1. Show the Mediterranean Sea on a map: bordered by three continents (Europe, Asia, Africa).
2. Review civilizations around it: Egypt, Greece, Phoenicia (Lebanon), Carthage, Rome (coming later).
3. The Mediterranean as a highway: safer and faster than land travel. Trade connected all these cultures.
4. What was traded: olive oil, wine, pottery, grain, metals, purple dye (Phoenicia), papyrus (Egypt).
5. The Phoenicians invented the alphabet! Letters traveled along trade routes.
6. Students trace Mediterranean trade routes on a map and draw traded goods.
7. Compare to the Silk Road: two great ancient trade networks.
materials_needed: Large map of the Mediterranean region
Blank outline map of the Mediterranean
Yarn or string for tracing trade routes

slides.heading: The Mediterranean World
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about the Mediterranean! It tells us we're going to learn about the big sea called the Mediterranean and how it helped people trade and connect a long, long time ago.

slides.setup_instructions: Print blank outline maps of the Mediterranean region. Display a large reference map showing all civilizations discussed. Have yarn ready for tracing trade routes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this activity, we need a few things to make our own map! We need a big map to look at, a plain map to draw on, colorful pencils to make it pretty, pictures of cool things people used to trade, and some yarn to show how they traveled. Go grab those with a grown-up!

slides.text: 'Look at the Mediterranean Sea on the map. It is surrounded by THREE continents: Europe to the north, Asia to the east, and Africa to the south. The word Mediterranean means middle of the Earth — the ancient world literally revolved around this sea!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at our big map! See this huge blue part? That's the Mediterranean Sea. It's like a giant bathtub, and it's got three big lands, called continents, all around it: Europe, Asia, and Africa. The name "Mediterranean" even means "middle of the Earth" because it was so important back then!

slides.text: 'Look at all the civilizations we have studied around its shores: Egypt here in the south, Greece here, and soon we will learn about Rome here. The PHOENICIANS lived here in modern Lebanon — they were the greatest sailors of the ancient world and they invented the ALPHABET that our letters come from! All these civilizations were connected by the sea.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these places around the sea! We've got Egypt, Greece, and soon we'll learn about Rome. And see this spot here? That's where the Phoenicians lived; they were amazing sailors and they invented our whole alphabet! All these places were connected by the water, like neighbors on a street.

slides.text: 'Ships carried goods across the Mediterranean: olive oil and pottery from Greece, grain from Egypt, purple dye from Phoenicia, metals from Spain. But they also carried IDEAS: the Phoenician alphabet, Greek philosophy, Egyptian mathematics. Trade connected and enriched every culture it touched — just like the Silk Road connected East and West!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This sea was like a superhighway for ships! It was much faster and safer to travel by boat than by walking or riding horses on land. Ships carried yummy food like olive oil and grain, pretty things like pottery and purple dye, and even important ideas, like that alphabet the Phoenicians invented.

slides.prompt: On your outline map: (1) Label all three continents and the Mediterranean Sea. (2) Mark and label: Egypt, Greece, Phoenicia, Carthage, Rome (for later!). (3) Draw trade routes connecting them across the sea. (4) At each civilization, write or draw 2 goods they traded. (5) Compare: how is Mediterranean trade similar to the Silk Road?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the map maker! On your blank map, write the names of the continents and the sea. Then, put little dots where Egypt, Greece, and Phoenicia are, and write down two things they traded. Finally, use your yarn to draw lines connecting them, like shipping routes, and think about how this is like the famous Silk Road!

slides.text: The Mediterranean Sea was the ancient world's greatest connector. Civilizations that might have remained isolated instead shared goods, ideas, and culture across the water. The alphabet you use to write came from the Phoenicians, across the Mediterranean to the Greeks, and eventually to us!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify civilizations around the Mediterranean, describe trade connections, and compare to the Silk Road?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You made an amazing map showing how the Mediterranean Sea connected all those ancient places. Remember how the Phoenicians gave us our alphabet? That all happened because people traveled and traded across this big sea, sharing ideas just like we share things today!

parent_notes: This lesson synthesizes previous studies by showing how all the ancient civilizations were connected. The Mediterranean as a 'highway' is a powerful concept. The Phoenician alphabet origin is particularly fascinating — our letter A comes from the Phoenician aleph (ox), turned upside down! This lesson sets up the coming study of Rome, which eventually dominated the entire Mediterranean world.

title: Greek Contributions — Architecture and Language
description: Students explore the lasting contributions of Ancient Greece to architecture (columns, the Parthenon) and language (Greek roots in English words). They discover how much of modern life has Greek origins.
instructions:
1. Greek architecture: three column styles — Doric (simple), Ionic (scrolls), Corinthian (leaves).
2. Show images of each column type. Find them in modern buildings (courthouses, museums, banks).
3. The Parthenon: temple to Athena in Athens. Perfect proportions, Doric columns.
4. Greek roots in English: graph (write), tele (far), phon (sound), bio (life), geo (earth).
5. Word-building game: combine Greek roots to make words (telephone, biography, geography, television).
6. Students draw all three column types and label them.
7. Create a Greek Root Word Web: one root in the center, words branching out.
materials_needed: Images of Greek columns and the Parthenon
Images of modern buildings with Greek-style columns

slides.heading: Greek Contributions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like our lesson's name tag! It tells us we're going to learn about all the amazing things people in Ancient Greece gave to the world, especially how they built things and the words we still use today. Isn't it cool that we can learn about things from so long ago?

slides.setup_instructions: Print images of Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian columns side by side. Find photos of local or famous buildings with Greek-style columns. Prepare a Greek root word reference sheet.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our art supplies ready for our Greek adventure! We'll need pictures of the different kinds of Greek columns, some pictures of buildings that look like they might have Greek columns, a list of those special Greek word parts, and of course, paper and pencils to draw and write. Go grab everything you need so we can get started!

slides.text: 'Ancient Greece gave us SO much that we still use today! Look at this building — see the tall columns? That style comes from Greece! There are three types: DORIC (simple and strong, like a plain cylinder), IONIC (with spiral scrolls at the top), and CORINTHIAN (decorated with carved leaves). You can spot these on courthouses, banks, and museums!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at these buildings! This slide shows us how the ancient Greeks were super good builders, and they invented these tall, fancy supports called columns. There are three main styles: the simple Doric ones, the Ionic ones that have cool curly swirls, and the really fancy Corinthian ones that look like they have leaves on top. You can still see these columns on important buildings today, like museums and courthouses!

slides.text: 'The most famous Greek building is the PARTHENON — a temple to the goddess Athena on a hilltop in Athens. It is considered one of the most perfect buildings ever constructed. Its proportions are so precise that it has influenced architecture for 2,500 years.' Show images and point out the Doric columns.
slides.mascot_explanation: This picture shows the most famous building from ancient Greece, called the Parthenon. It was a special temple built for a goddess named Athena, and the Greeks made it look so perfect that people still try to copy it today! See how it uses those strong Doric columns we just learned about? It's been around for thousands of years!

slides.text: 'Greece also gave us thousands of WORDS! Many English words have Greek roots. TELE means far, PHONE means sound — telephone means far-sound! BIO means life, GRAPH means write — biography means life-writing! GEO means earth, GRAPH means write — geography means earth-writing!' Build words on the board like a puzzle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to become a word detective! This slide shows us that many of the words we use in English actually come from ancient Greek, like secret codes. For example, 'tele' means 'far away' and 'phone' means 'sound,' so when you put them together, 'telephone' means 'far-away sound'! We're going to learn how to break down words like 'biography' and 'geography' too.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Draw all three column types (Doric, Ionic, Corinthian) and label each with its name and key feature. Part 2: Create a Greek Root Word Web. Choose a root (tele, graph, bio, geo, phon, or scope) and write it in the center. Branch out with all the English words you can think of that use that root.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to get creative! First, take your paper and pencils and draw those three kinds of Greek columns we saw – the Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian – and write their names next to them. Then, we're going to make a word web: pick one of those Greek word parts, write it in the middle, and then draw lines to write all the English words you can think of that use it!

slides.text: Greek contributions surround us every day: in our buildings, our words, our government, our sports, our theater, and our thinking. Next week, we continue with Greek philosophy and Alexander the Great — two more incredible Greek contributions to the world!
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the three Greek column types and use Greek roots to explain the meaning of English words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We learned how ancient Greeks were amazing architects who designed buildings with cool columns, and how they even gave us parts of our words. Think about all the buildings you've seen with columns and all the words you can now understand better – that's all thanks to the Greeks! Next time, we'll discover even more incredible things they gave us!

parent_notes: Greek roots are an incredibly powerful vocabulary tool. Once children learn common roots (tele, phone, graph, bio, geo, scope, micro, auto), they can decode hundreds of unfamiliar words. Make this a family game: spot a new word, find the Greek root, figure out the meaning. The column identification is also fun — go for a walk and find Greek-style columns on buildings in your area. They are everywhere!

title: Read Aloud — Greek Myth: Icarus and Daedalus
description: A read-aloud of the myth of Icarus and Daedalus, exploring themes of ambition, hubris (excessive pride), and the consequences of ignoring wise counsel. Students discuss the moral and connect to science (flight).
instructions:
1. Set the context: Daedalus was a brilliant inventor trapped on the island of Crete (connect to Theseus story — same labyrinth!).
2. Read the myth aloud: Daedalus builds wings of feathers and wax. He warns Icarus not to fly too high (sun) or too low (sea).
3. Icarus ignores the warning, flies too close to the sun, wax melts, he falls.
4. Discuss: Why did Icarus fly too high? (excitement, ambition, ignoring warnings).
5. The concept of HUBRIS: excessive pride or confidence that leads to downfall.
6. Science connection: Why would wax melt in heat? What makes flight possible?
7. Students write: 'The lesson of Icarus is...' and draw a key scene.
materials_needed: Greek mythology book with Icarus story

slides.heading: Read Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is just showing us the title of the story we're about to hear: "The Flight of Icarus." It's a famous Greek myth about a boy who flies too high!

slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate version of the Icarus myth. Have the map visible to show Crete — the same island from the Minotaur story!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for this adventure! We'll need the book with the Greek myth, a special notebook called a reading journal, some colored pencils and regular pencils for drawing and writing, and a map. The map is important because we'll see the island of Crete, which is where our story starts – it's the same island where the scary Minotaur lived!

slides.text: 'Remember the island of Crete from the Theseus story? After Theseus escaped the labyrinth, King Minos was furious. He locked up DAEDALUS — the brilliant inventor who built the labyrinth — and his son ICARUS. They were trapped on the island. How could they escape when Minos controlled the seas?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like a little introduction to our story. Remember when we learned about the hero Theseus and the maze called the labyrinth? Well, the inventor who built that maze, Daedalus, got trapped on the island of Crete with his son, Icarus. King Minos was super mad and didn't let them leave, and since he controlled all the boats, they were stuck!

slides.text: Read the myth with dramatic expression. Build tension as Daedalus constructs the wings. Emphasize Daedalus's warning: 'Do not fly too close to the sun, or the wax will melt. Do not fly too low, or the sea spray will weigh down the feathers. Follow me, stay in the middle.' Pause: 'Do you think Icarus will listen?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the story! Listen carefully as I read about how Daedalus, the clever inventor, made special wings out of feathers and wax. He told Icarus, "Don't fly too close to the sun, or the wax will melt, and don't fly too low near the sea, or the water will make the feathers heavy." He wanted Icarus to stay right in the middle. Do you think Icarus will listen to his dad?

slides.text: After reading: 'Why did Icarus fly too high? He was so excited by the feeling of flying that he forgot his father's warning. The Greeks called this HUBRIS — thinking you are above the rules, that warnings do not apply to you. Many Greek myths warn against hubris. It is still a lesson we need today.'
slides.mascot_explanation: After hearing the story, we need to think about *why* Icarus didn't listen. He was probably so excited about flying that he forgot his father's important warning! The ancient Greeks had a word for this kind of feeling: "hubris." It means being so proud or thinking you're so great that you believe rules don't apply to you. This is a big lesson in many Greek myths, and it's still important for us to learn today.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Draw the most dramatic moment of the myth. (2) Write: 'The lesson of the Icarus myth is...' in at least 3 sentences. (3) Answer: Can you think of a time when someone warned you about something and you wished you had listened? What happened?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be creative! Open your reading journal. First, I want you to draw the most exciting or important part of the Icarus story. Then, write down what you think the main lesson of the myth is, using at least three sentences. Finally, think about a time someone warned you about something, and you wished you had listened – write about what happened.

slides.text: The story of Icarus has been told for over 2,500 years because its lesson is timeless: listen to wise advice, know your limits, and beware of hubris. Daedalus represents wisdom and experience; Icarus represents youth and recklessness. Both characters live inside each of us.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student retell the Icarus myth, explain the concept of hubris, and articulate the story's moral?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job with the Icarus story! We learned that listening to advice from grown-ups who have more experience, like Daedalus, is super important. It's also good to remember our own limits and not get too carried away with excitement, which is what hubris is all about. You really understood the story and its amazing lesson!

parent_notes: The Icarus myth is one of the most powerful stories in Western literature. The concept of hubris appears throughout Greek mythology and is still relevant. Children naturally connect to the idea of ignoring warnings — they do it themselves! This is a great springboard for a deeper conversation about why we sometimes ignore advice even when we know it is wise. The science connection (wax melting, flight mechanics) adds another dimension.
